sub_topic: Finding the volume of a sphere inscribed in a cube.
message_1: A cube has a side length of 14 cm. What is the volume of the largest sphere that can be inscribed inside the cube? Round your answer to the nearest hundredth.
message_2:
The diameter of the largest sphere that can be inscribed inside the cube is equal to the side length of the cube. Therefore, the diameter of the sphere is 14 cm. The radius of the sphere is half of the diameter, which is 7 cm.

The volume of a sphere is given by the formula V = (4/3)πr^3, where V is the volume and r is the radius of the sphere.

Substituting the radius value into the formula, we get:

V = (4/3)π(7^3)
V = (4/3)π(343)
V ≈ 1436.76 cubic centimeters

The volume of the largest sphere that can be inscribed inside the cube is approximately 1436.76 cubic centimeters, rounded to the nearest hundredth.
